attributes.title: Selective Exposure on Chinese Social Media

q1.value: Selective Exposure on Chinese Social Media

q2.value: Clara Wang | Yusaku Horiuchi | Sean Westwood

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The objective of this research is to explore what factors might influence selective exposure in China – a country that is notorious for its strong information control measures. Selective exposure is a theory that posits individuals are more likely to select information that aligns with their beliefs. It is possible that selective exposure may lead Chinese citizens to read more information that does not follow Communist Party ideologies. It is also possible that social endorsements may drive Chinese netizens towards specific information channels that are less supportive of the regime. This phenomenon would suggest that social media networks have introduced a degree of “democracy” to authoritarian regimes, as individuals can encourage others to read information that is incongruent with the government’s issue alignment. This behavior may indicate that the Information Age poses a threat to the stability of authoritarian regimes. This study will clarify whether such effects exist. Few studies have examined selective exposure in authoritarian regimes. However, as the Internet makes information more accessible, the information environment has opened up in most authoritarian countries. A recent study suggests that selective exposure does play a role in information selection in China. Huang and Yeh (2016) found that Chinese citizens with higher pro-Western orientations are more likely to read articles that are critical of the Chinese government. Specifically, we will use a conjoint analysis design to examine how the following factors affect what articles Chinese netizens are more likely to select to read: (1) news topic, (2) congruence with the Chinese government’s issue alignment, (3) news source, and (4) number of social endorsements (e.g. “Likes”). We will also consider how the influence of each of the above factors is attenuated or increased by: (1) how often participants access a news source, (2) how much they trust a news source, (3) how nationalistic they are, and (4) how interested they are in political affairs.

q16.value: H1a: Chinese netizens are more likely to select articles that have topics related to government and politics (i.e. “hard” topics), as opposed to entertainment news (i.e. “soft” topics). H1b: Chinese netizens who are apathetic towards politics are less likely to select news articles related to politics (i.e. “hard” topics). H2a: Chinese netizens are more likely to select news articles that are incongruent with the Chinese government’s position. H2b: Individuals who are more nationalistic are more likely to select articles that are congruent with the Chinese government’s position. H3a: Chinese netizens are more likely to select articles from domestic, “commercialized” news sources than domestic, government news sources. H4: Chinese netizens are more likely to select news articles on social media that have more social endorsements and are perceived as more “popular.” RQ1: Will Chinese netizens’ selective exposure behavior vary with various demographic variables (i.e. age, political affiliation, rural/urban residence, education level, income level)? RQ2: Will frequency of access to a foreign news sources influence selective exposure behavior? RQ3: Will nationalism influence the likelihood that Chinese netizens select foreign news sources or trust foreign news sources? RQ4: If political interest has an influence on selective exposure behavior, will its effects vary based on whether the topic is foreign politics or domestic politics?

q17.value: Demographic variables were included to improve efficiency of our estimation, if necessary. Participants will be Chinese citizens age 18 and over recruited on the www.zhubajie.com online marketplace. All users on this online marketplace are eligible to participate in this study who meet the specified qualifications. The sample size will be approximately 1500 participants. Researchers have no role in selecting the participants after listing the project on www.zhubajie.com. We will use a conjoint experimental design in which all participants are shown 10 conjoint tables. These tables will have the same four attributes of information (news topic, news source, number of social endorsements, congruency with general Chinese media), but with randomized levels. We will use the Conjoint Survey Design Tool programmed by Anton Strezhnev to randomize the attributes in our conjoint tables. In each table, the attributes will be presented in the same order for all participants. However, each attribute (i.e. news topic, news source, etc.) will be randomized, which means that a level will be randomly selected for each attribute (e.g. for the news topic attribute, one of the levels – BBC, WSJ, Nanfang Dushi Bao, Renmin Ribao – will be randomly selected to be shown in that conjoint table). All randomized components will be independently randomized. Data will be collected on the www.zhubajie.com online marketplace platform. We will not know the identity of our participants prior to, during, or after the study, as we will only have information about their zhubajie.com usernames. We will not be able to connect these usernames to survey responses. Our primary outcome measure will be selection rates in the conjoint tables. (see attached document for further details). We will test for heterogeneous effects on the selection rates using the variables referenced in Hypotheses H1b, H2b, H3b. (see attached document for further details). We will calculate the average marginal component effect (AMCE) for each conjoint attribute. To analyze the heterogeneous effects of our other factors (i.e. Hypotheses 1b, 2b, 3b), we will repeat the AMCE procedure on subsets of the data. Subsets will be created by recoding survey measures to dichotomous variables.

attributes.title: Trust in Scientists and Conspiratorial Thinking

q1.value: Trust in Scientists and Conspiratorial Thinking: Evidence from A Conjoint Experiment

q2.value: Burak Sonmez, Kirils Makarovs, Nick Allum

q3.value: The objective of this study is to comprehend what kind of attributes people value when they trust or mistrust a scientist. For instance, do members of the public have a high opinion of female, liberal, or ethnic minority scientists? Do they tend to have a higher opinion of scientists working for the university than scientists working for the industry? Or does their trust depend on the scientific field that a scientist is engaged with? Last but not least, the study will shed light on how the public preferences for certain attributes of scientists interact with the tendency towards conspiratorial thinking and the appreciation of science in general. These questions have been relatively overlooked by the relevant experimental literature, in which the studies often neglect the multidimensionality of trust in science.

q4.value:
The main hypotheses of the study test how certain profile attributes contribute to the different dimensions of public trust in scientists. The respondents will receive the legend asking them to assess the credibility of the scientists’ profiles running for the made-up position of the scientific councilors’ board in their city/town. For each pair of profiles, the respondents will be asked to pick the one most credible and then assess both profiles on the different dimensions of trust.

H1. Drawing on the theory of social identity (Tajfel, 1974) and acknowledging the stereotypes about the educational achievements and knowledgeability of different racial/ethnical groups, we hypothesise that in all sub-dimensions of trust:

•	Asian scientists will be perceived as more trustworthy than other racial/ethnic groups (H1.1.)
•	Black and Hispanic scientists will be perceived as less trustworthy compared to white and Asian scientists. (H1.2.)

H2. Drawing on the same theory and building upon the gender-related stereotypes in science, we expect that:

•	Male scientists will be perceived as more trustworthy than female, and that this will be especially so in the context of epistemic trust.

H3. Considering the perceived prestige of the scientific fields (e.g. Gauchat and Andrews 2018), we expect to show that:

•	Scientists coming from the field of physics will be viewed as more trustworthy than those from other scientific fields, and this will be especially so in the context of epistemic trust (H3.1).

•	Scientists coming from the fields of physics, medical and environmental science will be viewed as more trustworthy than those from economics, and this will be especially so in the context of epistemic trust (H3.2).

H4. Looking at the domain of work attribute, we expect that:

•	Scientists coming from the industry will be viewed as less trustworthy in terms of the normative trust than those working for the university or the government (H4.1).

•	Scientists coming from the university will be regarded as more trustworthy in terms of the epistemic trust than those working for the industry or the government (H4.2).

H5. The literature suggests that the motivated reasoning and partisanship thinking (e.g. Lewandowsky and Oberauer 2016) is most acute when it comes to the polarisation drawn along the political spectrum. Given this, we decided to show the political leaning attribute to the randomly allocated half of the respondents, leaving the other half without this trait. Our hypothesis is that:

•	People will trust more those scientists who express the same political stance as they do, e.g. people who lean towards the Democratic party will be more trustful towards scientists who are Democrats rather than Conservatives, and this will hold in all types of trust (H5.1).

Also, considering the within-design interaction of the attributes, we hypothesise that:
•	The effect of the domain of work attribute on trust in scientist will vary across the values of scientist’s political leaning attribute (H5.2).

The next set of hypotheses implies interaction of the main attributes of scientists with the measures of respondent’s conspiratorial thinking, civic scientific literacy, and belief in science.

H6. Given that science-related conspiratorial theories consolidate more around the different scientific fields (e.g. medicine or environmental research) and domains of expert knowledge (e.g. government laboratories or industry) rather than the sociodemographic traits of the scientists, we hypothesise that:

•	For those scoring higher on the conspiracy mentality scale, the effect of medical science and environmental science on trust in scientists will be more negative than for those scoring lower on the conspiracy mentality scale (H6.1).

For those scoring higher on the conspiracy mentality scale, the effect of government and industry on trust in scientists will be more negative than for those scoring lower on the conspiracy mentality scale (H6.2).

Exploratory part of the analysis

The Belief in Science Scale measures public attitude to science as the superior form of knowledge about the world. In this part, we will explore two related questions: 

•	How do the effects of scientist’s race, gender, and political leaning on trust in scientists vary across the respondent’s scores on the belief in science scale?

•	How do the effects of scientific field and domain of work vary across the respondent’s scores on the belief in science scale?

The civic scientific literacy scale measures public knowledge of scientific facts and methodology. In this part, we will also explore two related questions: 

•	How do the effects of scientist’s race, gender, and political leaning on trust in scientists vary across the respondent’s scores on the civic scientific literacy scale?

•	How do the effects of scientific field and domain of work vary across the respondent’s scores on the belief in science scale?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
The respondents will receive the study link on Qualtrics platform that allows to implement the conjoint study design and to randomise the between-subjects treatment condition, the level of attributes, the order of attributes across tasks, question blocks, and the answer categories. There will be two between-subjects conditions (the profiles with attribute of political leaning vs the profiles without the attribute of political leaning). Following this between-subjects design, there will be 4 or 5 attributes with respect to their experimental condition, which will randomly vary in every round. There will be 5 rounds in total. You can find the levels of the attributes below. We also implement a constraint that prevents the occurrence of the same political leaning between the profiles. The pretest of the experiment has been carried out in January 2020 via MTurk (n=109) to ensure that the randomisation and the conjoint design work as expected. This data will not be stored later on, and no analysis will be subsequently conducted. The pre-registration is done before the main data collection has been administered.

•	Race/ethnicity (white, black, Hispanic, Asian)
•	Gender (male, female)
•	Political leaning (Independent, Democrat, Republican)
•	Scientific field (Physics, Medical science, Environmental science, Economics)
•	Domain of work (University, Government, Industry)

q9.value: Using JavaScript, we will randomise the attribute of political leaning at the between-subjects level. The level of attributes will be randomised in each task. The order of attributes will be randomised across each task. In addition, the question blocks, the order of questions, and the answer categories will be randomised to prevent the order effect.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study employs a 15-minute long survey on the U.S. nationally representative sample. The conjoint experiment will be carried out using the participant pool of Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/), and the data is to be collected in March 2020. The minimum payment in the UK will be respected for compensation of research participants. Participants must be at least 18 years old. There is no other sample restriction.

q13.value: The sample size will include 1,000 people. However, research subjects will take the experiment over 5 rounds. Therefore, the sample size will include 1,000 x 5 = 5,0000 observations.

question.value:
We manipulate the levels of these attributes (Race, Gender, Political leaning, Scientific field, Domain of work) in each task. 
•	Race/ethnicity (white, black, Hispanic, Asian), 4 levels.
•	Gender (male, female), 2 levels. 
•	Political leaning (Independent, Democrat, Republican), 3 levels.
•	Scientific field (Physics, Medical science, Environmental science, Economics), 4 levels.
•	Domain of work (University, Government, Industry), 3 levels.

For each pair of profiles, the respondents will be asked to pick the one most credible and then assess both profiles on the different dimensions of trust.

• Which of these two scientists do you prefer? 

We also distinguish between three dimensions of trust (general trust, epistemic trust, normative trust) and employ the following questions on a 7-point scale:

• How much would you trust Scientist A/Scientist B?

• How would you assess the qualifications of Scientist A/Scientist B to be the member of the Board of Scientific Councilors in your district?

• How much would you agree that Scientist A/Scientist B care about the best interests of the public when conducting their research?

The post-experimental questionnaire consists of:

•	Belief in Science Scale (BISS) – 7 items measuring the attitude to science as a source of superior knowledge about the world (Dagnall et al. 2019).

•	Civic Scientific Literacy Scale – 9 items measuring the general knowledge of scientific facts and methodology (Funk et al. 2019).

•	Conspiracy Mentality Questionnaire (CMQ) – 5 items measuring the predisposition to embrace the conspiratorial mindset (Bruder et al. 2013).

•	Endorsement of Conspiracy Theories – 3 items measuring the belief in specific conspiracy theories.

•	Sociodemographic questions – 11 items asking people’s age, race, gender, income, education, religiosity, political, etc.

To identify the distinct contribution of each attribute to the trust in the scientist’s profile we will regress four dependent variables including binary choice variable, general, epistemic, and normative trust variable on a set of dummy variables that take the value of ‘one’ if research subjects are exposed to the respective attribute. The regression models hence take the following form: 
                                                              Yijk = Xijkβ + eijk
where respondent i chooses scientist k in task j, and this is modelled as a function of Xijk, a vector containing the attributes of the scientist shown to the research subject in the task. Accordingly, we will calculate the average marginal component effects (AMCEs), or the average effect of changing each scientist’s attribute on the preferences for one scientist over another, relative to a baseline level. We will also estimate the average component interaction effects (ACIEs), as well as the conditional AMCEs to account for the heterogeneous treatment effects.

q25.value:
References

Bruder, M., Haffke, P., Neave, N., Nouripanah, N., and Imhoff, R. (2013). Measuring individual differences in generic beliefs in conspiracy theories across cultures: Conspiracy Mentality Questionnaire. Frontiers in psychology, 4, 225.

Dagnall N, Denovan A, Drinkwater KG and Parker A (2019) An Evaluation of the Belief in Science Scale. Front. Psychol. 10, 861.

Gauchat, G., and Andrews, K. T. (2018). The cultural-cognitive mapping of scientific professions. American Sociological Review, 83(3), 567-595.

Funk, C., Hefferon, M., Kennedy, B., and Johnson, C. (2019) Trust and mistrust in Americans’ views of scientific experts. Pew Research Center. Available at: https://www.pewresearch.org/science/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2019/08/PS_08.02.19_trust.in_.scientists_FULLREPORT-1.pdf

Lewandowsky, S., and Oberauer, K. (2016). Motivated rejection of science. Current Directions in Psychological Science, 25(4), 217-222.

Tajfel, H. (1974). Social identity and intergroup behaviour. Information (International Social Science Council), 13(2), 65-93.

•	Civic Scientific Literacy Scale – 9 items measuring the general knowledge of scientific facts and methodology (Funk et al. 2019).

•	Conspiracy Mentality Questionnaire (CMQ) – 5 items measuring the predisposition to embrace the conspiratorial mindset (Bruder et al. 2013).

•	Endorsement of Conspiracy Theories – 3 items measuring the belief in specific conspiracy theories.

•	Sociodemographic questions – 11 items asking people’s age, race, gender, income, education, religiosity, political, etc.
registration_responses.q19.question:
To identify the distinct contribution of each attribute to the trust in the scientist’s profile we will regress four dependent variables including binary choice variable, general, epistemic, and normative trust variable on a set of dummy variables that take the value of ‘one’ if research subjects are exposed to the respective attribute. The regression models hence take the following form: 
                                                              Yijk = Xijkβ + eijk
where respondent i chooses scientist k in task j, and this is modelled as a function of Xijk, a vector containing the attributes of the scientist shown to the research subject in the task. Accordingly, we will calculate the average marginal component effects (AMCEs), or the average effect of changing each scientist’s attribute on the preferences for one scientist over another, relative to a baseline level. We will also estimate the average component interaction effects (ACIEs), as well as the conditional AMCEs to account for the heterogeneous treatment effects.

q3.value: Donald Trump has downplayed the threat of the coronavirus. Social media posts and interviews from some of his supporters have also claimed that the threat has been exaggerated. Additionally, misinformation about the coronavirus has been circulated on social media. The purpose of this study is to examine how Republicans and Democrats differ in 1) their ability to discern true from false news headlines about the coronavirus, 2) their perceived vulnerability to the coronavirus, 3) their perceived severity of the virus, 4) their conspiracist beliefs about the coronavirus, 5) their perception of media exaggeration of the risks of the coronavirus, and 6) their estimates of the number of confirmed cases in the US, the number of confirmed cases worldwide, the number fatalities in the US, and the number of fatalities worldwide (at the day of data collection).

q4.value:
We predict that 
H1) participants will rate true headlines as more accurate than false headlines

He also predict that Republicans (compared to Democrats) will 
H2a) perform worse on news discernment, 
H3a) rate their vulnerability as lower, 
H4a) rate the severity as lower,
H5a) agree more with a conspiracy statement,
H6a) agree more with a media exaggeration statement, and
H7a) estimate fewer confirmed cases and fatalities. 

We will also compute correlational analyses and predict that 
H2b) will be negatively correlated with news discernment
H3b) will be negatively correlated with vulnerability ratings
H4b) will be negatively correlated with severity ratings
H5b) will be positively correlated with conspiracy ratings
H6b) will be positively correlated with media exaggeration ratings, and
H7b) will be negatively correlated with estimates and confirmed cases and fatalities.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a correlational design. For some analyses, there is one quasi-independent variable (political party: Republican, Democrat).

q13.value: We will have at least 176 Republican and 176 Democrat participants. We will likely have a sample much larger because some participants will not identify with either.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis with the smallest interesting effect (d = .30) for comparisons between Republicans and Democrats. With two-tailed alpha = .05, we need 176 participants in each group to obtain a power of .80. This will give us a power of .80 to detect correlations around r = .15.

q15.value: We will start by collecting data from 400 people and determine how many of them passed the honesty check questions and how many identified as Democrats and Republicans. We will continue to collect data in blocks of 50 until we have at least 176 participants who passed the honesty check questions in each group (Democrat and Republican).

question.value: None

We will measure: ratings to true and false coronavirus news headlines, perceived vulnerability to the coronavirus, perceived severity of the virus, conspiracist beliefs about the coronavirus, perception of media exaggeration of the risks of the coronavirus, and estimates of the number of confirmed cases in the US, the number of confirmed cases worldwide, the number fatalities in the US, and the number of fatalities worldwide (at the day of data collection). We will also measure political ideology (party, liberal-conservatism scale, and support for Trump).
News discernment will be calculated by subtracting mean ratings of fake headlines from mean ratings of true headlines.
We will test hypothesis 1 with a paired-samples t-test, hypotheses 2a-7a with independent samples t-tests, and hypotheses 2b-7b with Pearson correlations.

q21.value: We will set alpha = .05 and reject null hypotheses in cases in which the p-value is less than alpha.

q22.value: We will exclude data from participants who respond "yes" to either of the two honesty check questions (did they respond randomly to any items; did they look up any headlines/questions).

q23.value: Participants who do not rate more than one headline will be excluded. Participants who do not provide political party ratings or any of the coronavirus (threat, vulnerability, etc) ratings will also be excluded. Participants who do not identify as Republican or Democrat will be excluded from the between-group analyses, but they will be included in the correlational analyses.

q24.value: We will also explore how the level of support for Trump relate to responses on all tasks, including potential moderation of correlations.

attributes.title: Investigating moderators of the mnemic neglect effect

q1.value: When the self is in protection mode: Investigating moderators of the mnemic neglect effect

q3.value: A positive self-concept is essential for well-being and mental health (Taylor & Brown, 1988). One strategy to maintain a positive self-concept is neglecting negative self-concept-threatening information. This neglect becomes visible in a worse memory for self-concept-threatening information, a phenomenon known as mnemic neglect. To verify the self-protective nature of mnemic neglect and to better understand the underlying cognitive processes, we investigate three potential moderators: (a) narcissism, (b) self-esteem, and (c) type of recall task (free vs. cued recall). By investigating individual differences and the type of the recall task we aim to contribute to a better understanding of the mnemic neglect effect.

q4.value:
In the free recall task, 
a)	central negative behaviors will be recalled less frequently when referring to the self than to another person (Chris; replication of the mnemic neglect effect). There will be no substantial difference between the feedback referents (self vs. other) for central positive behaviors and for peripheral negative and peripheral positive behaviors.
b)	the mnemic neglect effect will not be substantially related to agentic narcissism, because the stimulus material is based on communal traits.
c)	the mnemic neglect effect will increase with increasing communal narcissism.
d)	the mnemic neglect effect will increase with increasing self-esteem.

In the cued recall task, the result pattern found in the free recall task will either be apparent to a weaker extent or not be substantial (reason: Presence of retrieval cues).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Reason: Participants see that the experimenter enters 1 or 2 on the screen. However, the participants do not know what the meaning of 1 and 2 is. There is no additional blinding in this study.

question.value:
Design:
We will use a 2 (feedback referent: Self vs. Chris; between-subjects manipulation) x 2 (feedback type: central vs. peripheral; within-subjects manipulation) x 2 (feedback valence: negative vs. positive, within-subjects manipulation) mixed factorial design.


Material:
The material (64 hypothetical behaviors) is adapted from Sedikides and Green (2000). It was translated into German, and slightly modified in order to provide unique retrieval cues. There are 16 behaviors for each combination of feedback type and feedback valence.


Procedure:
This study consists of two parts: An online questionnaire and a lab experiment. In the first part, participants will take an online questionnaire consisting of the German versions of the Narcissistic Personality Inventory (NPI-d; von Collani, 2014), the Communal Narcissism Inventory (CNI; Gebauer et al., 2012) and the Rosenberg self-esteem scale (RSES; von Collani & Herzberg, 2003). For each participant, the questionnaires are administered in a randomized order. The online questionnaire ends with demographic questions. In order to match the responses in the online questionnaire to the responses in the lab experiment, participants will receive an e-mail after finishing the online questionnaire. This e-mail contains a unique code they have to bring to the second part which takes place in the lab. After arriving in the lab, participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two feedback referents (Self vs. Chris). Both groups will be presented with 64 hypothetical behaviors in a randomized order. Each behavior will be presented for a minimum of 6 s on the computer screen. After 6 s, an instruction appears, that participants can now use the space bar to move on to the next behavior (cf. Study 4 by Zengel, Wells, & Skowronski, 2018). Participants in the self-condition will be asked to “consider the following description of yourself. Think of the description as being based on actual knowledge of people who know you well. Think of the description as real.” (Sedikides & Green, 2000, p. 913) In contrast, participants in the other-condition (Chris) will be asked to “consider the description of a person named Chris. Think of the description as being based on actual knowledge of people who know Chris well. Think of the description as real.” (Sedikides & Green, 2000, p. 913). The learning phase will be followed by a distractor task in which participants are asked to write down as many European capitals as possible within 2.5 min. After completion of this task, participants will perform a surprise free recall task. In this task, participants will have 5 min to enter as many behaviors as they can remember. Following previous studies, participants have to enter the behaviors one at a time in a response box that is cleared after the answer was submitted (cf. Newman et al., 2014; Study 2 by Zengel et al., 2018). The free recall task is followed by a cued recall task in which participants will be presented with a cue word (e.g., plant) and have to remember the respective behavior (e.g., X takes care of a colleague’s plants during vacations). The cue words will be presented in a randomized order. After completion of the cued recall task, participants will play Sudoku for 5 min as a distractor task. Thereafter, they will perform a second surprise free recall task and a second cued recall task. The second free and cued recall task resembles the first free and cued recall task. After completion of the cued recall task, they answer control questions (“How well could you imagine that the descriptions of X are real and based on the knowledge of people who know X well?”, “When reading the descriptions, did you expect to remember them later?”, “If yes, have you made special efforts to memorize the descriptions?”, “What do you think the study was about?”). Finally, participants are thanked and debriefed.

Note: The focus of the study lies on the first free and cued recall task. The second free and cued recall task are included for the model-based analysis (for more information see section exploratory analysis). We expect the result pattern of the first free and cued recall tasks to be similar to the second free and cued recall task, respectively. In each recall task, participants will be asked “to try to be accurate without worrying about recalling the behaviors verbatim.” (Sedikides & Green, 2000). In each free recall task, participants will also be instructed to recall as many behaviors as possible in any order they come to mind and to enter behaviors multiple times, wherever they are unsure whether they have already entered them. Participants will also be asked to enter parts of a behavior description if they don’t remember the complete description.

q9.value: Participants are assigned to the two conditions via simple randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited at the University of Mannheim through advertisements at the university, on social media, and via personal contacts. The sample will include 18 to 35-year-old German-speaking young adults. Participation will be rewarded with snacks, nonalcoholic drinks or small gifts. Data collection will probably start in March 2020.

q13.value: We will strive for a total sample of 128 participants (64 participants in the self- and 64 participants in the other-condition).

q14.value: We aim for a sample size that is in the range of sample sizes used by previous research on the mnemic neglect effect (e.g., Sedikides & Green, 2000; Newman et al., 2014; Zengel et al., 2018). To get a rough impression of the sample size needed, we also conducted an a priori power analysis with G*Power 3.1 (Faul et al., 2009). Assuming an ANOVA with a median split as analysis method, this analysis results in a total sample size of 128 participants given a medium effect size (f = .25), a conventional α-level of .05, and a target-power of 1 − β = .80. We expect that it will be difficult to find participants due to the low participation incentive and the two parts of the study. Furthermore, due to spatial restrictions, and organizational constraints, we are only able to use the lab for three weeks. Therefore, we won’t be able to recruit more than approximately 128 participants.

q15.value: Because of spatial restrictions, and organizational constraints, we will stop recruiting after three weeks. We will stop recruiting even if we have not reached the sample size of 128 participants for which we aim.

question.value: We will manipulate the feedback referent (self vs. Chris) between participants, and both the feedback type (central vs. peripheral) and feedback valence (negative vs. positive) within participants.

As outcome measures we will assess the number of correctly recalled behaviors in free and cued recall. Following previous research, two raters will determine independently from each other whether the gist of the recalled behavior matches the originally presented behavior. If the gist of the recalled and the original behavior matches, it is coded with 1, otherwise with 0. Specifically, intrusions – recalling a behavior that was not present, recalling the same behavior more than one time, and recalling the behavior but with the opposite valence – will be coded with 0 (cf. Sedikides & Green, 2000). Correctly remembered cues in the free recall task will also be coded with 1, otherwise with 0.
Additionally, for the moderator variables agentic narcissism, communal narcissism, and self-esteem, we will calculate the respective sum scores based on the assessed answers in the three questionnaires (NPI-d, CNI, RSES).
As control variables we will assess the gender of the participants.
No indices will be computed.

In order to replicate the mnemic neglect effect, we will conduct a mixed ANOVA which is the commonly used method in previous research. We will conduct a mixed ANOVA on the first free and cued recall task as outcome variables. Both mixed ANOVAs will have three factors: One factor manipulated between participants (feedback referent) and two factors manipulated within participants (feedback type, feedback valence). A significant three-way interaction of feedback referent, feedback type, and feedback valence indicates the presence of the mnemic neglect effect. 
To investigate individual differences, we will perform hierarchical regression analyses with an ordinary least square regression model for the first free and cued recall task, respectively. In the first step we will include gender as a control variable. In a second step we will include the predictors feedback type, feedback valence, and feedback referent. The moderator variables agentic narcissism, communal narcissism, and self-esteem follow in a third step. Next, all two-way interactions are included in a fourth step. In a fifth step, all three-way interactions are included. The four-way interactions are included in a sixth and final step. Especially the four-way interaction of feedback referent, feedback type, feedback valence and personality trait is of interest. We will also explore interactions that are relevant for our hypotheses by simulating quantities of interest.
Although not in the focus of our study, we will perform the mixed ANOVAs and hierarchical regression analyses with the second free and cued recall task as outcome variables.

q20.value: For mixed ANOVAs, effect coding will be used for categorical variables (e.g., feedback referent: -1 = self, 1 = other; feedback type: -1 = central, 1 = peripheral; feedback valence: -1 = negative, 1 = positive). For hierarchical regressions, the sum scores of the three questionnaires (NPI-d, CNI, RSES) will be z-standardized before including them as predictors. Dichotomous categorical variables will be coded with 0 and 1 for regression analyses (i.e., dummy coding for feedback referent: 0 = self, 1 = other; feedback type: 0 = central, 1 = peripheral; feedback valence: 0 = negative, 1 = positive, gender: 0 = male, 1 = female).

q21.value: An alpha level of .05 is applied in all analyses. We will use p-values as inference criteria for all analysis.

q22.value:
We will apply the following exclusion criteria:
a)	Participants did not finish both parts of the study (i.e., the online questionnaire and the lab experiment).
b)	Participants are not fluent in German or younger than 18 or older than 35 years (self-report).

q23.value: Missing data is imputed (mean imputation) wherever possible. Otherwise, the case is excluded from the analysis.

q24.value:
Model-based analysis:

Currently, there are two explanations for mnemic neglect: The first explanation states that mnemic neglect is caused by weak encoding of self-concept-threatening information. According to this explanation, people shift attention away from self-concept-threatening information, thereby encoding this information only on the surface. The second explanation states that mnemic neglect is caused by difficulties to retrieve self-concept-threatening information. In order to investigate the question, whether encoding, retrieval or both processes contribute to mnemic neglect, we propose the Encoding-Maintenance-Retrieval (EMR) model (Küpper-Tetzel & Erdfelder, 2012). This model is tailored to a free-then-cued-recall-paradigm and provides separate measures for successful encoding of behavior descriptions (e), maintaining encoded descriptions (m), and retrieving stored behavior descriptions in a free recall task (rf). In order to apply the model, a second free and cued recall task are included in the study. This is the first attempt to fit the EMR-model on mnemic neglect data. Because only 16 behaviors for each combination of feedback type and feedback valence are used in this study, no hierarchical analysis can be performed to account for individual differences. Therefore, we will only fit the aggregated model in this study. If the application of the model is successful, we will conduct another study in which we use only central negative and positive behaviors to fit the hierarchical model in addition to the aggregated model in order to investigate the impact of individual differences on the underlying cognitive mechanisms. 

For the model-based analysis we have the following predictions:
Encoding parameter (e): According to the first explanation, mnemic neglect is (partially) due to weak encoding. If this explanation holds, the probability of encoding a central negative behavior successfully (parameter e) will be lower in the self- than in the other-condition (Chris). There will be no substantial differences in the encoding parameter e between the feedback referents (self vs. other) for central positive behaviors and for peripheral negative and peripheral positive behaviors.
Maintenance parameter (m): According to the two assumptions thought to underlie mnemic neglect (weak encoding, retrieval difficulties), the probability of storing a successfully encoded central negative behavior (parameter m) should not substantially differ between the self- and other-condition (Chris). It should be comparable with the maintenance of peripheral negative behaviors as well as central and peripheral positive behaviors in the self and other-condition. 
Retrieval parameter for the free recall task (rf): According to the second explanation, mnemic neglect is (partially) due to retrieval difficulties. If this explanation holds, the probability of successfully retrieving a central negative behavior in the free recall task (parameter rf) will be lower in the self- than in the other-condition (Chris). There will be no substantial differences in the free recall retrieval parameter rf between the feedback referents (self vs. other) for central positive behaviors and for peripheral negative and peripheral positive behaviors. 

For the model-based analysis we will exclude participants who did not recall any behaviors or correctly recalled all behaviors in the first cued recall task. If necessary, we will increase the rigorousness of the criterion by restricting the range, for example including only participants with equal to or more than 20% and equal to or less than 80% correct answers in the first cued recall task. This criterion is necessary in order to prevent problems with fitting the MPT model. We plan to fit the model with 5,000 iterations (default in multiTree). However, we will increase the number of iterations if necessary. Model fit is assessed by the goodness of fit statistic G^2. In order to evaluate differences between the self- and other-condition (Chris), the difference in the goodness of fit statistic between a baseline model and an alternative model is used (∆G^2).


Possible further exploratory analyses:

If there are many dropouts between the first part (online questionnaire) and the second part of the study (lab experiment), we will investigate the characteristics of the participants who dropped out (e.g., whether they are low in self-esteem). 
We will also investigate the impact of narcissism and self-esteem on the mnemic neglect effect by using a median split in order to include agentic narcissism, communal narcissism and self-esteem in a mixed ANOVA.
Furthermore, we will explore whether there are differences in recalling central positive behaviors referring to the self or to another person (Chris) and whether this is associated for example with communal narcissism.

To get a rough impression of the sample size needed, we also conducted an a priori power analysis with G*Power 3.1 (Faul et al., 2009). Assuming an ANOVA with a median split as analysis method, this analysis results in a total sample size of 128 participants given a medium effect size (f = .25), a conventional α-level of .05, and a target-power of 1 − β = .80. We expect that it will be difficult to find participants due to the low participation incentive and the two parts of the study. Furthermore, due to spatial restrictions, and organizational constraints, we are only able to use the lab for three weeks. Therefore, we won’t be able to recruit more than approximately 128 participants.
registration_responses.q15: Because of spatial restrictions, and organizational constraints, we will stop recruiting after three weeks. We will stop recruiting even if we have not reached the sample size of 128 participants for which we aim.
registration_responses.q20: For mixed ANOVAs, effect coding will be used for categorical variables (e.g., feedback referent: -1 = self, 1 = other; feedback type: -1 = central, 1 = peripheral; feedback valence: -1 = negative, 1 = positive). For hierarchical regressions, the sum scores of the three questionnaires (NPI-d, CNI, RSES) will be z-standardized before including them as predictors. Dichotomous categorical variables will be coded with 0 and 1 for regression analyses (i.e., dummy coding for feedback referent: 0 = self, 1 = other; feedback type: 0 = central, 1 = peripheral; feedback valence: 0 = negative, 1 = positive, gender: 0 = male, 1 = female).
registration_responses.q21: An alpha level of .05 is applied in all analyses. We will use p-values as inference criteria for all analysis.
registration_responses.q22:
We will apply the following exclusion criteria:
a)	Participants did not finish both parts of the study (i.e., the online questionnaire and the lab experiment).
b)	Participants are not fluent in German or younger than 18 or older than 35 years (self-report).
registration_responses.q23: Missing data is imputed (mean imputation) wherever possible. Otherwise, the case is excluded from the analysis.
registration_responses.q24:
Model-based analysis:

Currently, there are two explanations for mnemic neglect: The first explanation states that mnemic neglect is caused by weak encoding of self-concept-threatening information. According to this explanation, people shift attention away from self-concept-threatening information, thereby encoding this information only on the surface. The second explanation states that mnemic neglect is caused by difficulties to retrieve self-concept-threatening information. In order to investigate the question, whether encoding, retrieval or both processes contribute to mnemic neglect, we propose the Encoding-Maintenance-Retrieval (EMR) model (Küpper-Tetzel & Erdfelder, 2012). This model is tailored to a free-then-cued-recall-paradigm and provides separate measures for successful encoding of behavior descriptions (e), maintaining encoded descriptions (m), and retrieving stored behavior descriptions in a free recall task (rf). In order to apply the model, a second free and cued recall task are included in the study. This is the first attempt to fit the EMR-model on mnemic neglect data. Because only 16 behaviors for each combination of feedback type and feedback valence are used in this study, no hierarchical analysis can be performed to account for individual differences. Therefore, we will only fit the aggregated model in this study. If the application of the model is successful, we will conduct another study in which we use only central negative and positive behaviors to fit the hierarchical model in addition to the aggregated model in order to investigate the impact of individual differences on the underlying cognitive mechanisms. 

For the model-based analysis we have the following predictions:
Encoding parameter (e): According to the first explanation, mnemic neglect is (partially) due to weak encoding. If this explanation holds, the probability of encoding a central negative behavior successfully (parameter e) will be lower in the self- than in the other-condition (Chris). There will be no substantial differences in the encoding parameter e between the feedback referents (self vs. other) for central positive behaviors and for peripheral negative and peripheral positive behaviors.
Maintenance parameter (m): According to the two assumptions thought to underlie mnemic neglect (weak encoding, retrieval difficulties), the probability of storing a successfully encoded central negative behavior (parameter m) should not substantially differ between the self- and other-condition (Chris). It should be comparable with the maintenance of peripheral negative behaviors as well as central and peripheral positive behaviors in the self and other-condition. 
Retrieval parameter for the free recall task (rf): According to the second explanation, mnemic neglect is (partially) due to retrieval difficulties. If this explanation holds, the probability of successfully retrieving a central negative behavior in the free recall task (parameter rf) will be lower in the self- than in the other-condition (Chris). There will be no substantial differences in the free recall retrieval parameter rf between the feedback referents (self vs. other) for central positive behaviors and for peripheral negative and peripheral positive behaviors. 

For the model-based analysis we will exclude participants who did not recall any behaviors or correctly recalled all behaviors in the first cued recall task. If necessary, we will increase the rigorousness of the criterion by restricting the range, for example including only participants with equal to or more than 20% and equal to or less than 80% correct answers in the first cued recall task. This criterion is necessary in order to prevent problems with fitting the MPT model. We plan to fit the model with 5,000 iterations (default in multiTree). However, we will increase the number of iterations if necessary. Model fit is assessed by the goodness of fit statistic G^2. In order to evaluate differences between the self- and other-condition (Chris), the difference in the goodness of fit statistic between a baseline model and an alternative model is used (∆G^2).


Possible further exploratory analyses:

If there are many dropouts between the first part (online questionnaire) and the second part of the study (lab experiment), we will investigate the characteristics of the participants who dropped out (e.g., whether they are low in self-esteem). 
We will also investigate the impact of narcissism and self-esteem on the mnemic neglect effect by using a median split in order to include agentic narcissism, communal narcissism and self-esteem in a mixed ANOVA.
Furthermore, we will explore whether there are differences in recalling central positive behaviors referring to the self or to another person (Chris) and whether this is associated for example with communal narcissism.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Design:
We will use a 2 (feedback referent: Self vs. Chris; between-subjects manipulation) x 2 (feedback type: central vs. peripheral; within-subjects manipulation) x 2 (feedback valence: negative vs. positive, within-subjects manipulation) mixed factorial design.


Material:
The material (64 hypothetical behaviors) is adapted from Sedikides and Green (2000). It was translated into German, and slightly modified in order to provide unique retrieval cues. There are 16 behaviors for each combination of feedback type and feedback valence.


Procedure:
This study consists of two parts: An online questionnaire and a lab experiment. In the first part, participants will take an online questionnaire consisting of the German versions of the Narcissistic Personality Inventory (NPI-d; von Collani, 2014), the Communal Narcissism Inventory (CNI; Gebauer et al., 2012) and the Rosenberg self-esteem scale (RSES; von Collani & Herzberg, 2003). For each participant, the questionnaires are administered in a randomized order. The online questionnaire ends with demographic questions. In order to match the responses in the online questionnaire to the responses in the lab experiment, participants will receive an e-mail after finishing the online questionnaire. This e-mail contains a unique code they have to bring to the second part which takes place in the lab. After arriving in the lab, participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two feedback referents (Self vs. Chris). Both groups will be presented with 64 hypothetical behaviors in a randomized order. Each behavior will be presented for a minimum of 6 s on the computer screen. After 6 s, an instruction appears, that participants can now use the space bar to move on to the next behavior (cf. Study 4 by Zengel, Wells, & Skowronski, 2018). Participants in the self-condition will be asked to “consider the following description of yourself. Think of the description as being based on actual knowledge of people who know you well. Think of the description as real.” (Sedikides & Green, 2000, p. 913) In contrast, participants in the other-condition (Chris) will be asked to “consider the description of a person named Chris. Think of the description as being based on actual knowledge of people who know Chris well. Think of the description as real.” (Sedikides & Green, 2000, p. 913). The learning phase will be followed by a distractor task in which participants are asked to write down as many European capitals as possible within 2.5 min. After completion of this task, participants will perform a surprise free recall task. In this task, participants will have 5 min to enter as many behaviors as they can remember. Following previous studies, participants have to enter the behaviors one at a time in a response box that is cleared after the answer was submitted (cf. Newman et al., 2014; Study 2 by Zengel et al., 2018). The free recall task is followed by a cued recall task in which participants will be presented with a cue word (e.g., plant) and have to remember the respective behavior (e.g., X takes care of a colleague’s plants during vacations). The cue words will be presented in a randomized order. After completion of the cued recall task, participants will play Sudoku for 5 min as a distractor task. Thereafter, they will perform a second surprise free recall task and a second cued recall task. The second free and cued recall task resembles the first free and cued recall task. After completion of the cued recall task, they answer control questions (“How well could you imagine that the descriptions of X are real and based on the knowledge of people who know X well?”, “When reading the descriptions, did you expect to remember them later?”, “If yes, have you made special efforts to memorize the descriptions?”, “What do you think the study was about?”). Finally, participants are thanked and debriefed.

Note: The focus of the study lies on the first free and cued recall task. The second free and cued recall task are included for the model-based analysis (for more information see section exploratory analysis). We expect the result pattern of the first free and cued recall tasks to be similar to the second free and cued recall task, respectively. In each recall task, participants will be asked “to try to be accurate without worrying about recalling the behaviors verbatim.” (Sedikides & Green, 2000). In each free recall task, participants will also be instructed to recall as many behaviors as possible in any order they come to mind and to enter behaviors multiple times, wherever they are unsure whether they have already entered them. Participants will also be asked to enter parts of a behavior description if they don’t remember the complete description.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited at the University of Mannheim through advertisements at the university, on social media, and via personal contacts. The sample will include 18 to 35-year-old German-speaking young adults. Participation will be rewarded with snacks, nonalcoholic drinks or small gifts. Data collection will probably start in March 2020.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the feedback referent (self vs. Chris) between participants, and both the feedback type (central vs. peripheral) and feedback valence (negative vs. positive) within participants.
registration_responses.q17.question:
As outcome measures we will assess the number of correctly recalled behaviors in free and cued recall. Following previous research, two raters will determine independently from each other whether the gist of the recalled behavior matches the originally presented behavior. If the gist of the recalled and the original behavior matches, it is coded with 1, otherwise with 0. Specifically, intrusions – recalling a behavior that was not present, recalling the same behavior more than one time, and recalling the behavior but with the opposite valence – will be coded with 0 (cf. Sedikides & Green, 2000). Correctly remembered cues in the free recall task will also be coded with 1, otherwise with 0.
Additionally, for the moderator variables agentic narcissism, communal narcissism, and self-esteem, we will calculate the respective sum scores based on the assessed answers in the three questionnaires (NPI-d, CNI, RSES).
As control variables we will assess the gender of the participants.
registration_responses.q18.question: No indices will be computed.
registration_responses.q19.question:
In order to replicate the mnemic neglect effect, we will conduct a mixed ANOVA which is the commonly used method in previous research. We will conduct a mixed ANOVA on the first free and cued recall task as outcome variables. Both mixed ANOVAs will have three factors: One factor manipulated between participants (feedback referent) and two factors manipulated within participants (feedback type, feedback valence). A significant three-way interaction of feedback referent, feedback type, and feedback valence indicates the presence of the mnemic neglect effect. 
To investigate individual differences, we will perform hierarchical regression analyses with an ordinary least square regression model for the first free and cued recall task, respectively. In the first step we will include gender as a control variable. In a second step we will include the predictors feedback type, feedback valence, and feedback referent. The moderator variables agentic narcissism, communal narcissism, and self-esteem follow in a third step. Next, all two-way interactions are included in a fourth step. In a fifth step, all three-way interactions are included. The four-way interactions are included in a sixth and final step. Especially the four-way interaction of feedback referent, feedback type, feedback valence and personality trait is of interest. We will also explore interactions that are relevant for our hypotheses by simulating quantities of interest.
Although not in the focus of our study, we will perform the mixed ANOVAs and hierarchical regression analyses with the second free and cued recall task as outcome variables.

attributes.title: Experimental test of framing and herding effects on the activation of populist attitudes

q1.value: Experimental test of framing and herding effects on the activation of populist attitudes

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Most studies of populism have focused on the leader or party and the supply of voters or support this generates. Starting from the assumption of substantial “latent” demand for populism among voters, this work theorizes and empirically tests the extent to which herding behavior activates populist attitudes as a response to a normative threat framed by the media and interpersonal communication (or public opinion data). By applying an experimental design to the study of populism, my thesis adds to the literature on populist politics by proposing a new causal mechanism that seeks to understand the activation of populist attitudes to be partly driven by herding, i.e. the seeking of cohesion with the attitudes of others. The project will involve two experiments of approximately ten minutes for online participants to take part in an online panel run by Amazon Mechanical Turk. The two experiments will consist of four main parts: 1) all participants will be asked to fill out a questionnaire on their political attitudes and background (4 minutes); 2) participants will be randomly assigned a specific scenario about a fictitious issue (either framed in a pluralist or a populist manner) and will then be asked to answer two questions on the basis of this scenario (3 minutes); 3) participants will be randomly assigned a second set of information about the scenario (experiment 1: interpersonal frame; experiment 2: opinion poll data) and then be asked to answer a short question on the basis of the additional information (2 minutes); 4) and render a final decision on the preceding scenario and additional information (1 minutes). The results will be used for an MPhil thesis (and published in an academic journal).

q16.value: H1 The strongest populist response follows when the specific framing of a threat involves both the populist media frame and the populist interpersonal frame (or opinion poll majority). The degree of the framing effect, i.e. activation of populist attitudes, should be more pronounced in non-competitive framing environments in comparison to competitive framing environments. H2 The strongest pluralist response follows when the specific framing of involves both the pluralist media frame and the pluralist interpersonal frame (or opinion poll majority). H3 Any single populist frame moves the participant toward a more populist evaluation of the scenario. H4 The populist attitude of a perceived majority according to opinion poll data, as a proxy measure for herding, will influence the likelihood of populist attitude activation H5 The effects on the activation of populist attitudes tested under H1–H3 are stronger among individuals with higher latent populist attitudes. H6 The effects on the activation of populist attitudes in H1–H3 are larger among individuals with a lower interest in politics.

q17.value: To empirically test the suspected herding and framing effects on the activation of latent populist attitudes at the individual level, two Amazon Mechanical Turk experiments (both: N=1000) will be implemented. Relevant for the study of interpersonal framing in the context of populism, the experiments permit fictitious personal interactions between participants to be isolated. The experiments introduce new treatment designs and outcome measures. All treatments and controls are fictitious. Both experiments expose participants either to a pluralist (control) media frame and the other half the same news article along with a populist (treatment) frame. In the first experiment, these media frames are followed by either a pluralist (control) interpersonal cue, or a populist (treatment) interpersonal cue. In the second experiment, those same media frames are followed by either opinion data suggesting a pluralist (control) majority, or opinion data suggesting a populist (treatment) majority.

q18.value: United States of America, United Kingdom

q19.value: Two expertments with 1000 participants each (2000 participants total)

q24.value: Research Ethics Approval: Ref No.: SSH_DPIR_C1A_18_007

attributes.title: The effect of foreign language in moral judgment: The role of psychological distance
attributes.description: In order to explore the possible factors affecting the generation of foreign language effect, we hypothesized that psychological distance was related to foreign language effect and designed experiments to verify the hypothesis. The researchers of this project came from Department of psychology, Renmin University of China.

summary.value:
Previous search has demonstrated that foreign language effect might be attributable to an increase in psychological distance. However, the effect of psychological distance on foreign language effect has not been investigated in moral judgment. Two experiments were conducted to explore whether the psychological distance influences the foreign language effect in moral judgments. In experiment 1, participants were presented with seven moral dilemma stories (3 stories with close psychological distance and 4 stories with distant psychological distance) in either English or Chinese language. In experiment 2, participants were randomly assigned to close or distant psychological distance conditions (4 moral dilemma stories with unfamiliar victims or parent/child victims). The two experiments found a significant effect of foreign language in moral judgment with distant psychological distance, whereas no significant effect of foreign language in moral judgment with close psychological distance. The present findings demonstrated that the psychological distance might be an important role of moderating the foreign language effect in moral judgment.

Keywords: Foreign language effect; Moral judgment; Psychological distance
